name: sodium borate mine operation and beneficiation | sodium borates | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/26786/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of sodium borate from borax (also called tincal), a naturally occurring mineral containing boron in form of B2O3.  After being extracted from open pit sites and crushed, the ores are ;dissolved in water and screened to separate the resulting insolubles from the solution. Sodium borate is especially used in household products, such as detergents and disinfectant. This dataset consider the production of sodium borate occurring at global scale and is an extrapolation of the respective geography US.;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - sodium borates production, GLO, 2000 - 2000 (6e17aa57-2f68-4837-981a-de178261fedd)]

The activity starts with the mining of borax (Na2B4O7*10H2O) from the ground. 

The activity ends with the production of sodium borate (anhydrous).
category: B:Mining and quarrying/08:Other mining and quarrying/089:Mining and quarrying n.e.c./0891:Mining of chemical and fertilizer minerals
tags: Sector: Resource Extraction; Minerals; Agriculture & Animal Husbandry

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data used are assumed to represent global conditions.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Sodium borates are obtained from surface mining of borax (Na2B4O7 * 10H2O) deposits, also called tincal. Open pit mining requires drilling and blasting to reach load deposits. Ores are removed from the mine and transported to milling and beneficiating plants for concentrating the ore. After being crushed, the ores are ;dissolved in water and screened to separate the resulting insolubles from the solution. The crystals of sodium borate are dried from the solution and can either be sold as anhydrous borax or treated further to produce other borate materials.;References: ;US EPA. Archive document - Boron. Available at: https://archive.epa.gov/pesticides/reregistration/web/pdf/0024fact.pdf;US Borax, 2019. Boron operations brochure. Available at: https://www.borax.com/BoraxCorp/media/Borax-Main/Resources/Brochures/boron-operations.pdf
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from the original dataset covering the geography TR. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: The data are extrapolated from the US dataset.

exchanges.description:
Water pumped from well for exploration and drilling programs. Approximation from the pre-feasibility study of colemanite deposits in Mexico (Chapter  21.0 Capital and operating coast, Table 22): 50k tonnes of water  are required for 50k tonnes of colemanite.  

Reference:
Allard, G., Salazar Velazquez, R., Verley, C.G., Vidal, M.F., 2013. Preliminary Economic Assessment for the El Cajon Borate Deposit, Magdalena Basin Project, Sonora, Mexico (Pursuant to National Instrument 43-101 of the Canadian Securities Administrators).

exchanges.description:
Calculated value, based on the B2O3 content in both borax ores (26-27%) and in sodium borate (32-33%), The recovery rate of B2O3 is 78.7%. 

Reference: 
Acarkan, N., Bulut, G., Kangal, O., & Önal, G. (2005). A new process for upgrading boron content and recovery of borax concentrate. Minerals Engineering, 18(7), 739-741.

flow.name: Gangue
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description:
Literature. Particulates are generated from the dryers, and have an average diameter of 44um. 

References: 
Energy and Environmental Profile of the U.S. Mining Industry, 2013. Chapter 3: Potash, Soda Ash, and Borates. Table 3-6, Available at:  https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2013/11/f4/potash_soda_borate.pdf
U.S.E.P.A. 1980. Source category survey: Borax and Boric acid industry. 58 pp.

exchanges.description:
Amount taken from the dataset "sodium borates production" (GLO) as published in ecoinvent v3.8, based on Althaus et al. (2007). 

Reference:

flow.name: Transformation, from forest, unspecified
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description:
Calculated value based on boron content in natural borax in ground. Approximation from borax deposits in Turckey. Acarkan et al. (2005) report that borax ore of 26-27% B2O3 is treated to produce a concentrate having 32-33% B2O3. Recovery rate is 78.7%. B MW = 10.81 g/mol; O MW = 16 g/mol

Reference: 
Acarkan, N., Bulut, G., Kangal, O., & Önal, G. (2005). A new process for upgrading boron content and recovery of borax concentrate. Minerals Engineering, 18(7), 739-741.
